Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Characterizing the Chemical and Physical Signature of the 2015-16 El Nino in the Quelccaya Ice Cap Snow and Ice to Calibrate Past ENSO Reconstructions
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award uses funds, under the auspices of the Rapid Response Research (RAPID) concept, to dig three new snow pits and collect two new ten-meter long cores from the Quelccaya ice cap (QIC) in southern Peru. Samples from these pits and cores will be physically and chemically analyzed to address the hypotheses that post-depositional features (e.g., melt features) and elevated concentrations of dry deposited trace species (e.g., black carbon, dust, ammonium) provide new and reliable markers of past El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) events and also help facilitate the quantification of the event's intensity. These new markers will be also applied to other ice cores from the southern Andes that exist from extended tropical ice core archives collected over the last forty years.

The chemical and physical fingerprints of past El Niño events are preserved in ice cores from Andean glaciers, particularly the QIC, and offer the potential to quantify past regional ENSO variability. Previous isotopic (delta 18-Oxygen) records from the QIC provided a long annually resolved history (1,800 years) of Pacific sea surface temperature (SST) variations. However, delta 18-O on the QIC is also influenced by other internally varying climate system processes (e.g., South American Monsoon, ITCZ position). Consequently, additional El Niño proxies are needed to reduce the uncertainties inherent in past El Niño reconstructions and to help facilitate more accurate projections of intensity and frequency.

The new data that could result from the research is aimed at testing two hypotheses: 1) the snow melt and percolation induced by El Niño is identifiable in the prior year's snow layer and can be calibrated to the El Niño's strength in terms of temperature and radiative forcing; and 2) the concentration and co-association of biogenic and evaporitic species will be enhanced and detectable deeper in the ice and thereby reveal past El Niño frequency.

The potential broader impacts include capturing the chemical and physical signatures of a modern El Niño event in real time that could help evaluate past ENSO variability preserved in ice cores as well as assessing the role of solar forcing in climate. The research will help support an early career female scientist and the research results will be disseminated in short video segments appropriate for the public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF-RAPID Project Outcome Report 1/3/2018

NSF Award #1603377

Lonnie G. Thompson (PI), Emilie G. Beaudon, co-PI

The El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) is the primary natural source of climate variability in the tropical Pacific region. However, its frequency and amplitude have been unusual during the 20th century, suggesting that the influence of man-made (anthropogenic) climate change may be superimposed on the ENSO dynamics.

By November 2015, Pacific Sea Surface Temperature (SST) anomalies had reached +3°C in the mid-tropical Pacific region, setting the stage for one of the strongest El Niño episodes in the last 100 years. El Niño, the warm phase of ENSO, has pronounced impacts that differ regionally across South America. For example, Peru usually experiences flooding in its northern and central regions and drought conditions on the Altiplano in the south. However, the 2015/16 El Niño event resulted in drought throughout the Peruvian Andes, creating conditions favorable for enhanced surface ablation (mass loss) of glaciers.

The majority of the precipitation in central and southern Peru falls during the austral summer (December to February). At high altitudes, the wet season snow is stored in the glaciers in the Andes and on the Altiplano, making them the main source of fresh-water during dry periods. Moreover, they are vital assets for the environmental and economic well-being of Peru. Since Andean ice fields are sensitive to seasonal hydrological contrasts, they also act as indicators of climate variability and change. El Niño episodes, which occur every 2 to 7 years, regularly disrupt the climate of tropical South America and alter the wet season precipitation regime over the Andes.

The research supported by this award was designed to study the direct impact in a warming world of the 2015/2016 El Niño event on the largest tropical ice field on Earth, the Quelccaya ice cap (5670 m above sea level, masl) in southeastern Peru. Our glaciological expedition to Quelccaya was conducted several weeks after the climax of this very strong El Niño event, allowing the recovery of its freshly formed signature in terms of snow accumulation and post-depositional processes (i.e., melting and percolation, sublimation and/or diffusion). The thickness of the annual snow layer was determined from the snow stratigraphy, and moisture origin was deduced from measurements of the ratio of oxygen isotopes (δ18O) in the snow collected in a shallow (10 m) ice core and a 1.9 m snow pit (Photograph 1).

 

 The results of this project emphasize the impact of this El Niño event when it is placed in the perspective of a 42-year long glaciological survey effort conducted by our group on the summit of Quelccaya which is the world’s longest monitored tropical ice cap. We found that during the 2015/2016 season, the snow accumulation on the glacier was the smallest measured since 1974 (the layer thickness was 64% smaller than the 42-year average).  This indicates that this El Niño event enhanced the impact of the ongoing warming that is taking place in the tropical Andes (Figure 1). The ice wastage was also visible at the margin of the glacier (Photograph 2).

Our results are very useful for the calibration of mass balance models and the prediction of the dynamic response of the ice cap to future El Niño events coupled with the anticipated enhancement of atmospheric warming. This knowledge is of immediate relevance for Peruvian production of hydroelectric power, irrigation and the water supplies for the communities that subsist directly and almost exclusively on glacial meltwater, especially during the dry season and drought periods.

During the same expedition to Peru, our group climbed to the col of the Huascarán glacier (6000 masl), where a 10-meter ice core was drilled and sampled. Considering the extent of the recent warming at high altitudes in Peru, the discovery of a well-preserved seasonal climate signal (i.e., δ18O) within the top 10 m of the glacier was unexpected (Thompson et al., 2017). Fortunately, it presents a new opportunity for the extraction of what could possibly be the last unmodified (i.e., original) ice core climate record from the inner tropics.

This project created the opportunity for researchers and post-docs to observe and document the impact of the 2015-2016 El Niño on the glaciers in northern and southern Peru. In particular, our 2016 field campaign on Quelccaya provided the opportunity for a Peruvian undergraduate student to be included (at no cost) in the expedition where he received his first ice core drilling experience.

 

Thompson, L. G., M. E. Davis, E. Mosley-Thompson, E. Beaudon, S. E. Porter, S. Kutuzov, P-N. Lin, V. N. Mikhalenko, and K. R. Mountain. 2017. Impacts of recent warming and the 2015/16 El Niño on tropical Peruvian ice fields.  J. Geophys. Res. Atmos., 122. https://doi.org/10.1002/2017JD026592.
